title: Who will win the 2020 New Hampshire Democratic primary?
preds: Polls close in an hour.  There are three post-debate polls.  Bernie's average is about 29 percent.  The closest person trailing is Buttigieg with an average of about 21 percent.  None of the others are close.   Actually, I think the probabilities should be 80 Bernie, 20 Buittigieg and 0 percent others.  The 100 percent is due to extremizing.

On February 11th, Real Clear Politics Polling Data (Located at: https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html) shows Sanders with a 7.3 % lead over Buttigieg (28.7% and 21.3% respectfully).   For my "other" category Klobuchar is at 11.7%.  While Bloomberg is surging across National polls, he hasn't spent much of his resources in New Hampshire, in my view making it unlikely he would win a write-in campaign there.  Warren and Biden are both polling at 11%, in my opinion making it unlikely either will win in New Hampshire.  Therefore I am now putting Sanders at 70% with Buttigieg at 30%.  I am dropping all other candidates to 0% based on polling data. I am still predicting Sanders winning, but now with a greater percentage potential

A whole new set of polls released on the eve of the Primary all show a Sander's victory above the margin of error, with Buttigieg in a strong second place. Further confirming that any other candidate will surely not win except in the case of a huge unforeseen upset.  The Polls show an increase of support for Bernie in the high twenties, above the percentage needed to win Iowa, while after an initial increase of support after Iowa, Buttigieg's support seems to be holding steady at around 20%. Therefore, it is not unforeseeable for Buttigieg to win, but still unlikely.
Updating based on Iowa results and updated polling data.
Polls showing Klobuchar surging, Biden collapsing.

Biden got 60% in 2016. Nepotism optics and his own stumbling diminishing his shine. Mayor Pete is coming up but how far? Sanders state is nearby but health concerns might hurt him. Thinking perhaps. someone else has a surprise chance.

Adjusting Sanders up in light of most recent polls (and averages of recent polls). 
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html
Update: Dropping Biden -10%- he stated during the debate that NH will probably go the same way as Iowa for him...
Forecasts continue to indicate a lead for Sanders despite increased momentum for Buttigieg.  All others trailing considerably.

Looking at the polls over the last week show that Sanders has an average lead of 5 points. My model suggests that primary candidates who have a lead of that magnitude will go on to win 60-65% of the time. Because of how Iowa turned out I'm going to go with the low end of that range and say Sanders has a 61% chance. In addition to the above metric I'm going to factor in other forecasts. FiveThirtyEight has given Sanders a 64% chance while the exchange markets are much more confident at 75%. With these two forecasts in mind I'm going to push my initial forecast up to 64%. As far as the rest are concerned it does look as though Buttigieg is the main contender. However, Biden, Warren et al. are not that far behind so it would be foolish to rule them out completely.
Forgot to update my Buttigieg odds.

We now have our first post-debate New Hampshire polls, and Bernie is way in the lead.  (+7 and +8).  Hence, the New Hampshire debates did not have much of an effect.  On one hand, this is not too surprising since they have debated several times before.  On the other hand, there is still a large undecided group -- or group which indicated it could switch candidates-- and Buttigieg unexpectedly won Iowa.   Conventional wisdom is that Buttigieg is competing with Biden.   The polls do show that when Biden rises Buttigieg falls and vice versa.  Right now Biden is rising that hurt Buttigieg's chance for a win.  Finally, all the others are far too far behind to catch Bernie.  If they were not, it would have shown up in the polls already.   https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html

I think after New Hampshire, Biden will be seen as irrelevant, with expectations finally catching up to reality. The truth is, he was always irrelevant. I'll give Buttigieg 5% chance, however, as an acknowledgement that I didn't expect his impressive showing in Iowa.

Updating in light of "final" Iowa outcome, related 538 aggregation in the wake of Iowa, New Hampshire debate performance, and Biden's active expectation management, all of which seem to align with Sanders solidifying his lead and Buttigieg making a significant late advance.

Bernie still has the home field advantage.  However, Buttigieg and Klobachur did well in the debate.  Normally, it takes a few days for the impact of a good or bad debate performance to fully register in the polls.    Nevertheless, the Boston TV station's poll showing Buttigieg in the lead appears to be an outlier right now.  Monday's polls will be very important, not just because they will have been completed just prior to the primary, but also because they will be the first polls where  all  participants will have been polled after the debate.
Sanders won in 2016. The rest of the participants are yet to convincingly differentiate themselves from the pack.
Sanders remains ahead in the polls and his lead has actually increased in some in the last few days.
I'm sticking pretty close to the fivethirtyeight.com forecast.

I knew the debate would create large swings in the polling.  I just saw a tracking having Buttigieg with a slight lead over Sanders.  Sanders still has the home state advantage being from next-door Vermont.   Close elections cratered my Briar score in Kentucky and Louisiana.  I thought this would be different -- until today. It is getting interesting.
Cry havoc and let slip the Sandernistas!

Mayor Pete is his ground game. Meet voters in their homes and have a pleasant policy conversation while avoiding the more incendiary topics that can erupt in town halls. He rising above the knife fight on stage between Biden and Bernie. They are not a pleasant New Hampshire B & B, B & B can't help but serve as Icons of all of the sorry history in D.C.

Bernie is leading in the polls, and he is from Vermont -- right next door.  The people in the populated areas of New Hampshire, I understand, watch the Vermont television news every night.  Hence, Bernie has a home town advantage that does not always carry though to the end of the primary season, e.g., Paul Tsongas from  Massachusetts  in 1992 and Bernie in 2016. Therefore, I think more interesting questions would be what is the margin of error and who will finish second.  Buttigieg's chances increased greatly since Iowa, but Bernie has lead by a wide margin in every New Hampshire poll.   Unfortunately, I missed the debate, but we will know more about any possible changes after the over-night polls come in.

Adjusting for most recent polls, which show a spike in Buttigieg's numbers following his apparent success in Iowa, somewhat constant support for Sanders, and slowing of Biden.  https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html#polls

First of all Bernie has been the leader in every New Hampshire polls since January 16th. Furthermore, many of these are above the margin of error. These polls give Bernie an average support of 25%, which is only 1-2% less than the 26% needed to "win" Iowa. Furthermore, New Hampshire polls show surprising support for Tulsi Gabbard at around 4-6%. Tulsi supporters are very similar to Bernie supporters and when push comes to shove, I predict a fair number of them will vote Bernie for practical reasons on election night.  After Buttigieg's surprising performance in Iowa, he has captured media attention and has the "momentum" heading into New Hampshire. Newly released polls easily show this momentum with an influx of support by as much as 10%. Buttigieg has yet to overtake Bernie in the polls though. Moreover, it shouldn't be forgotten that Bernie did with the popular vote in Iowa, and the New Hampshire Primary will be decided by the popular vote. Furthermore, Bernie does have a semi-homefield advantage in New Hampshire, just as Buttigieg, as a midwesterner, had an advantage in appeal for Iowa. Buttigieg does not have this appeal in the rest of the early primary states. Therefore, It is plausibly that Buttigieg's momentum will continue to grow for him to overtake Bernie, but still unlikely. Biden's campaign took a real stumble after Iowa and while Biden was never polling great in New Hampshire, his numbers have crumbled since Iowa. It is highly unlikely his campaign will recover in the next week to win New Hampshire. Therefore, I predict that due to his negative momentum and previously losing polling numbers, there is no way Biden can win New Hampshire.  While Warren does have a semi home advantage in New Hampshire, especially among the more populous Southern New Hampshire, as is the case with all her polling, after her media craze before the new year, her poll numbers have predictably dropped into the mid teens in the early primary states. Furthermore, the polling data for her performance in Iowa was not terribly far off, leading me to believe that her polling data in New Hampshire won't be terribly far off either. On election night, she will probably have a resurgent swell of support, similar to Iowa, but it will not be enough to more than double her support. Therefore, I predict Warren also has no chance in winning New Hampshire.

Sanders consistently leads the polls and is the only candidate to consistently make the 15% threshold.[1] I give him an 80% chance of winning due to this.  Buttigieg and Biden are level pegging but I give Buttigieg the edge due to momentum.  Second choice votes do not come into play here like in Iowa so the threshold is more significant, hence a stronger emphasis on a single candidate for me here compared to Iowa.  [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/new-hampshire/
Resetting my forecast closer to the 538 model. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/new-hampshire/

I updated my forecast because of the IOWA Caucase. 
https://www.businessinsider.com/iowa-caucus-2020-live-results-vote-counts-updates-2020-2

Recent polling (after the Iowa debacle) show a slight increase for Buttigieg, with Sanders still commanding a large lead. Adjusting Buttigieg to equal with Biden and will await further polling later this week. Warren also looks to be losing traction and will adjust her down slightly accordingly. 
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html

Update- Dropping Biden 10% (splitting evenly between Sanders/Buttigieg who did well in Iowa) He underperformed in Iowa which is a big red flag for his campaign even though it has been mostly swept under the rug given the chaos with the caucus and other things in the news cycle (impeachment, state of the union, etc.)

Based on the data from Project FiveThirtyEight (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/new-hampshire/) Biden and Sanders have been fluctuating back and forth for who is ahead in the polls. However, most recently, Sanders has been experiencing an upward trend in the polls whereas Biden is experiencing a downward trend in the polls. Similarly, but on a smaller scale, Warren is experiencing a slight upward trend whereas Buttigieg is experiencing a slight downward trend. Based on this data from the most recent polling- most trends last at least a week. Therefore I expect that by the New Hampshire primary next week, not much should change in terms of trends. That is why I place a lower percentage on Warren and Buttigieg and I place a higher percentage for winning the primary on Sanders and Biden with the prediction that Sanders still has a higher chance of winning than Biden as based on current trends.
I'm feeling like Biden is done. 5% "other" is most for Bloomberg.
After Iowa, giving my 1% token chance to Buttigieg.
Going with a fairly neutral estimate for today until we hear a result from Iowa.
Revising Sanders upwards as he maintains a steady lead in the polls.
Back to bullish on Sanders. I can't see any of the other candidates pulling it off.
I think Bernie has been a major force in New England
Updating with latest poll averages from fivethirtyeight.com

The last debate appears to have had a large impact on the polls and the likelihood of Bernie Sanders winning the event.  Biden remains a "safe" choice in most cases, but at the local level the support seems to be moving more toward Sanders.

Updated polling (https://americanresearchgroup.com/pres2020/primary/dem/nhdem20-01.html) shows Sanders taking the lead in New Hampshire primary. This poll also shows other candidates, such as Gabbard and Yang, increasing in popularity, though still not significant enough to rank in the top four candidates. Reporting also suggests that Biden has pulled back in his campaign efforts in New Hampshire, suggesting that he doesn't expect to win the primary in this state (https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/28/biden-new-hampshire-2020-107296).

Updating forecast- 
Politico reporting that Biden is putting NH on "the backburner" instead intensifying focus on Iowa and Nevada. I'm taking this as either meaning that the Biden camp feels locked that they'll win NH or that they have no shot. Considering that no polling shows Biden as a lock- I'm taking it as a sign weakness.  
Looking forward- still going to keep an eye for any surprising outcomes out of Iowa/any extremely good or bad debate performances

Sanders continuing to lead in various polls covering N.H. primary: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-sanders-is-on-the-upswing/ https://www.nbcboston.com/news/politics/sanders-seizes-the-momentum-in-nh-nbc10-boston-franklin-pierce-herald-poll-shows/2068088/
Sanders has a clear lead in the polls with Buttigieg polling second.
Biden been winning up to now, Sanders is his main opponent, Warren campaign is imploding, everyone else say 5%

Received following from the Economist Data Journalist. Slightly different perspective than I’d seen previously but ties a couple points together. FYI only
“The Democratic Party is yet to hold its first presidential primary, but many would-be nominees have already surged, sagged or dropped out altogether. Joe Biden has been the front-runner ever since pollsters started asking primary voters about their intentions. But just behind him, there has been plenty of movement. Elizabeth Warren had a surge in the autumn, nearly but not quite catching Mr Biden; she has since fallen back. Next to enjoy a bounce was Pete Buttigieg, who benefited from Ms Warren’s declining popularity among college-educated whites. His numbers have now slid a bit and Bernie Sanders is doing better. What explains these ups and downs?
Almost all of the variation in support for the different Democratic candidates so far can be traced to movement among white voters, particularly college-educated ones. According to YouGov’s survey for The Economist of Democrats who say they intend to vote in the primaries, the group has oscillated wildly between support for Ms Warren, Mr Sanders and Mr Buttigieg. This has been the main group supplying Mr Biden’s chief competitors—Mr Sanders and Ms Warren—with enough votes to be contenders. Ms Warren pulled in support from over 20% of college-educated whites at the start of the campaign, and currently wins nearly 30% of them. Mr Sanders has recently become the leading choice of whites without a degree.
Non-white Democratic voters, by contrast, have been much more stalwart in their support for Mr Biden, especially those without college degrees. They have grown only more inclined to the former vice-president as the more progressive candidates have swapped places behind him.
This is, on the face of it, odd. During President Donald Trump’s administration, white, liberal Democrats have become much more sensitive to racial injustice than they were when Barack Obama was president. You can see this in their increased awareness of racial discrimination as a barrier to economic and social progress. Yet when it comes to casting a vote in the primaries, they have avoided non-white candidates. They also favour more radical policies than do African-Americans. It used to be labour unions that acted as a counterweight to left-wing social movements within the Democratic coalition. Now it seems that African-Americans are playing that role. Without them, Ms Warren or Mr Sanders, not Mr Biden, would probably be the favourite.“

Sanders appears to be leading, but the most recent poll (Suffolk)  is somewhat misleading. While it shows Sanders with a wide margin, the poll combines both individuals who both currently support a candidate or are "leaning" toward a candidate. The leaning voters could easily change their mind. Prior recent polling (without leaning factored in) shows a much closer race, with a large segment still undecided. Results in Iowa, where recent polls are few and appear to indicate a tighter race, could influence NH voters to a certain extent. Nevertheless, Sanders won by a large margin in 2016 and he is well-known in New Hampshire. The difference, however, was there were really only 2 viable candidates in 2016--Sanders and Clinton. Sanders consistently led in polling averages in the month leading up to the primary by 8-10 points, with increasing support as the election neared. He ultimately won 60/38%. Here, on the other hand, 4 candidates make the assessment more complicated, as Biden and Sanders carry less than 50% support (about 40-45%) between the two of them, with Warren and Buttigieg garnering close to 30%. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html
Since the NH primary is only a week after the Iowa caucus, it seems unlikely that any of the four will drop out unless they do incredibly poorly. We can thus expect a fairly divided support. Buttigieg has surged recently, and some of the other policy questions reveal an independent streak in voters that he could appeal to.

Some recent polls show Sanders at the top for N.H.: https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/23/politics/trump-pew-poll-break-law/index.html? https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/new-hampshire/

Bernie Sanders is the favorite to win in New Hampshire.  He won NH in the 2016 Democratic Primary by a margin of more than 22% of the vote over Clinton.   According to a recent WBUR poll, Sanders has almost doubled his support among Democratic voters in NH since December, giving him a solid lead.  Additionally, Sanders has devoted a lot of his resources towards winning NH.  I do not assess that Biden will be willing to invest the same amount of resources for a likely lost cause in NH.  I assess the recent polls showing Sanders pulling away is the beginning of the surge.

Bernie is from neighboring Vermont and has an independent steak, which New Hampshire is notorious for (live free or die state). Warren from neighboring MA or Biden, who has senior and moderate support, could sneak in.
Believe moderate will be the more likely choice.  Regarding someone else, if Amy Klobucher comes in 3rd or above in Iowa she would be a strong possibility in NH
Upping Biden's odds on the off chance that he performs well in Iowa. No one, including him, expects him to, however.

Multiple sets of polling data show Biden and Sanders in the lead- and separated by small percentage points. Sanders is from Vermont and may command more votes due to that proximity.  Biden, a former senator from Delaware, will also draw the "familiar' vote. I gave Sanders the edge over Biden because he won NH  in 2016.    I don't believe there is an outside of the box "someone else" that will win the primary.

New Hampshire voters are not decisive enough to vote one candidate to prevail others. Therefore, the Iowa caucus at Feb 3 will be important for candidates to be selected. Not the winner but the candidates not to be supported higher than 15% will be determiner to set the winner. Joe Biden is the most likely, Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders are the probably, and Elizabeth Warren is the possible winner of the primary. Someone else is not likely to be the winner. This forecast should be reassessed after Feb 3, Iowa caucus.

Candidates only get delegates if they get over 15% of the vote. Since the start of 2020, only Biden and Sanders have consistently reached this threshold.[1] Therefore currently I think 80% chance one of them will win. I am leaning towards Sanders over Biden because:
- Sanders won the State in 2016 [2]
- Close to home state advantage (he’s from Vermont)
- Result swung towards him as the ‘less establishment’ candidate in 2016 [3] However,
- As @likethebird said, less enthusiasm for Sanders this time around [4] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/new-hampshire/

Bernie Sanders won the NH primary in 2016 and, since he is from the area, is likely to win again. However, Elizabeth Warren is also from the area and may be able to pull additional popular support as well. Joe Biden is known in his own right while Pete Buttigieg is certainly becoming better known, but I think it is unlikely at this point that they will win more votes than Sanders.

The other candidates know Sanders is the person to beat (released info re black Americans stumping for Biden even though devil in details, Warren finally taking a swing at over unproven misogynist remark that a woman can’t beat Trump, Biden team pushing the Bernie-is-a-solcialist/communist attack subtly, Biden team admitting he’s gaffe prone but warm - esp. for those needing a neck massage). All this could add up to a Biden win as that’s who the DNC want to win. Sanders has the target on his back but is better at defending himself than the others (Warren also good in this regard).
Admit polls show only a slight lead for Sanders. He and Buttigieg are the only ones generating real enthusiasm IMO although Warren does it in a technocratic, and sometimes gender-centric way.

Bottom line: still think Sanders has the chops. Admit it will be close. And I doubt there will really be a knockout winner in either Iowa or New Hampshire.
"You have a friend in PA. Only candidate that is strong enough to go up against Trump.

Sanders leads in current polling, per 538, though only marginally. He also leads in fundraising, per 4th quarter 2019 FEC filings; the lead fundraiser has been the New Hampshire winner more than half the time, so giving Sanders a 15% bump over initial base rate estimate of a four way race. Biden is a close second in 538's aggregated polls, with ~20% support, and is the only candidate to break 30% support since April 2019, so adding 5%. Biden is third in fundraising behind Mayor Pete who, along with Elizabeth Warren, are currently both polling around at close to 15%.  It's too early to tell what impact Booker's exit might have. Iowa has predicted New Hampshire 50% of the time in Democratic primaries since the 1970s, setting aside Iowa Senator Tom Harkin's victory, so the results will be worth considering, particularly if they deviate significantly from this prediction.

Already adjusting from my first forecast after reading some of the other predictions and reconsidering my base rate strategy, which I think may have anchored me high considering the factors that are unique to 2020 (namely the number of candidates fundraising amounts in the same relative ballpark). So my change here is to increase the amount I am letting the polls and five thirty eight's forecast influence me, bumping Biden up and bringing Bernie down. However, I did not want to drop Bernie below 50% minimum because I still agree with my overall assessment. Will watch and update.

I started by finding a base rate for the past five democratic primaries in New Hampshire (2000-2016): how often the lead fundraiser as of the end of the fourth quarter of the preceding year won the New Hampshire primary. This happened 3 out of 5 times (Obama 2012, Clinton 2008, Gore 2000), or 60%. So because Bernie Sanders is the lead fundraiser, I start with him at a 60% chance of winning the most delegates. While I'm going with this for now, to see where it leads, I do have some reservations: primarily that in most of the past NH primaries I cited, there were not SO many candidates with solid fundraising numbers. So I might reneg on this approach later.  Next for the inside view. Five thirty eight also has Sanders as the most likely to win, with Joe Biden a close second. For this I will give Sanders 5% extra since we’re already starting with a pretty high base rate, and also reward Biden by putting him at 25%. The polls reflect this too, however Biden has been on a slight downswing and Bernie on an upswing over the past months. So I’ll leave my forecasts as is for that. Other factors in Bernie’s favor: he has a proximity to home state advantage, he just snagged a huge union endorsement, and he won the last NH primary. So I’m thinking I’m going to put Bernie above 70%.  However, Biden might find an extra boost from the fact that Bloomberg is not on the NH ballot and forecasts/polls do show him close to Bernie. So I want to give him a little extra for that.  Moving on to Buttigieg, he’s seen huge upward momentum in New Hampshire, while he polls a little lower overall, so I don’t want to ignore the way things are moving and want to give him some points for that. I want to give him 15%, but am starting to realize that my numbers will not add up and I need to look at the whole picture.
Before I do that, I’ll turn to Warren. Based on polling, five thirty eight prediction, and fundraising, her chances look low considering that her primary policy competitor, Sanders, has the advantages I described above. So I will cap it at 10% as of now. And the other candidates: while I think there is momentum brewing that could change later races, I don’t think that’s going to happen before New Hampshire, based on polling data, considering that Yang did not qualify for the Jan 14 debate, and looking at fundraising data.  So in the end, I’m using my intuition based on the factors I’ve listed here to settle on the exact probabilities for my prediction. In the end I find myself feeling like I want to raise the probabilities on the candidates other than Bernie, but based on the facts I’ve laid out I feel like I can’t justify dropping him below 65% minimum. I will be updating.  Sources:

“It would surprise me if an underdog won. At this point, it would be near-impossible for someone to beat Biden, Warren, Buttigieg and Sanders, given their campaign and field operation. The other surprising thing could be the number of voters who are unaffiliated with a party who take Democratic ballots in the open primary. That will go up significantly, and if not, that would be very surprising.” – Melanie Levesque, New Hampshire state senator “At this point in 2016, Sanders was at 50 percent in the polls. He ended up winning with about 61 percent. Now he’s in the mid-20s. That’s a pretty significant loss of support, yet the media seems to think he is doing well. The media is also missing the potential that there may be no clear winner here. Any candidate who finishes with more than 15 percent of the vote picks up delegates under the party rules. Let’s say there are four people who win delegates, then we’re on to Nevada and South Carolina!” – Kathy Sullivan, former New Hampshire Democratic Party chairwoman

Using 538's 2020 primary forecast as baseline: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/new-hampshire/ Bumping Bernie very slightly based on his recent fundraising numbers (https://www.cnbc.com/video/2020/01/06/bernie-sanders-leads-the-democratic-pack-in-fourth-quarter-fundraising.html) and Boston Globe's article on Friday naming Bernie as "the candidate to defeat" . Keeping the bump small because I saw his campaign is facing criticism from other democrats on social media today for "going negative" on Warren. I want to see if this news disappears or becomes  something bigger (https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/11/bernie-quietly-goes-negative-on-warren-097594) The most current national polling for Democratic primary winner shows Buttigieg dropping and Warren rebounding slightly, so I lowered Buttigieg and increased Warren marginally (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/national/)  I put a >0 value for "someone else" because of the high number of undecided voters in NH, and Klobuchar's recent NH polling (5th place) and endorsement from former state lawmaker Pete Burling (globe article) Going forward I plan to monitor endorsements, analysis of Booker's exit, and news on Iowa polling.

Updating forecast:
Bumping Buttigieg 5%-  think my initial forecast was too low upon further reflection/conversations also hedging for momentum that could be gained leading up to/post Iowa
Bumping Sanders 8%-  recent key endorsement from NH unions [1]
Dropping Warren 2%- other candidates seem to be gaining momentum here while Warren has been staying about the same
Dropping Biden 11%- might've been overly optimistic in initial forecast, and union endorsement for Sanders is showing he has real momentum and a strong coalition in the state Things to keep an eye on going forward: 
- Debate (if anyone has a particularly strong/weak performance, who the candidates perceive as the front runner)
- Additional endorsements
- Iowa, in particular how candidates do in relation to expectations (if someone does worse than expected that is a bad sign going forward) [1] https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/12/sanders-union-endorsement-new-hampshire-097911

Working primarily off of 538 model's forecasts, but adding a 15% bump to Sanders' chances. Sanders outperformed polls and predictions in New Hampshire in 2016 by around 5% of votes. My guess is that NH's proximity to VT will drum up support which is not currently reflected in the polls.

Buttigieg 10,230 Bernie Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton in the primary receiving 60.1% to Clinton’s 37.7%. Sanders claimed 15 of the NH delegates to Clinton’s 9.  Prediction markets have Sanders at $0.51, Biden at $0.24, Buttigieg at $0.17, and Warren at $0.10 [5], but we have to keep in mind how poorly prediction markets performed in 2016.  According to five thirty eight, Sanders has a 30% chance of winning the most delegates, while Biden has a 35% chance. Buttigieg is prediction is have a 21% chance of winning and Warren a 16% chance. [5] Monmouth poll that came out today had Buttigieg’s poll numbers doubled since September, and Warren’s dropped [2].  From @likethebird, 42% of the electorate in NH is independent, and get to choose what primary to vote in, some of those who voted Republican in 2016 may vote in the Democratic primary and prefer a more centrist candidate [6]. Using the five thirty eight as a base rate, I am revising Sanders slightly above Biden given his previous support in the state over a centrist. Outside view:
Biden- 67%, Buttigieg- 3%, Sanders- 13%, Warren- 17%
I used FiveThirtyEight's NH primary polling average[1], which goes back to mid March, to establish a base rate  Inside view:
- Warren's campaign has fallen 13 points in the polls since her lead in oct-nov [2] (-8%) and her supports second choice candidates breakdown 33% Sanders, 24% Biden, 12% Buttigieg [3] (+4%, +3%, +1% respectively)
- Sanders has been on a slow rise, and seems to be surging now but appears tied with Biden, who has been picking up momentum [1,2] (+15% Sanders- big jump but most of Biden's lead was during Summer 2019, so minds might've changed since and probably some support on name recognition)
- Sanders also has an incredibly loyal and engaged base that will turn out during the primary [2] (+3%)
- NH electorate skews wealthier/older which is a good thing for Biden [4] (+1%)
- Sanders won 2016 by +20%, but this time is different (less apparent enthusiasm, fewer key endorsements) [5, 6] also because Independents (who make up 42% of electorate [7]) can vote in either primary, so some who voted Republican 2016 may vote for a more centrist Dem in 2020 (+2% Biden, +4% Sanders, +1% Buttigieg)
- Sanders has the highest number of campaign offices in NH, demonstrating his investment in the state (+1%) Other things to note:
- There has been lots of academics research that debates have less impact once voters are already familiar with a candidate and their ideas[8], but still would keep an eye for an extremely good/poor performance by any candidate 
- There haven't been many endorsements by individuals in NH, so also would pay attention to if/when they come out because could have a big influence on the winner Sources:

[3] https://morningconsult.com/2020-democratic-primary/
[4] https://morningconsult.com/2016/02/06/eleven-maps-that-explain-new-hampshires-political-geography/
[5] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/25/us/politics/bernie-sanders-new-hampshire-2020.html

[8] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-we-know-about-the-impact-of-primary-debates/

Based on RCP poll average for NH https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html , but taking into account the most recent national polls show Sanders and Warren gaining momentum, and Buttigieg losing momentum.

Polling as of 5 January has Biden and Sanders in a dead heat, but the two of them are only 8pts above 4th place Pete Buttigieg.  Biden holds a "comfortable" 9pt lead when you look at the national numbers.  With about a month to go, candidates will start pushing in their additional resources to claim an early win in the process.  Sanders performed well here in 2016, snagging over 60% of the vote.    The most recent YouGov poll results shows a majority of the respondents are considering Biden, Sanders, and Warren (all three at or over 50%), while Pete Buttigieg trails with only 42%.  It also appears support for their one candidate is starting to solidify with 83% of respondents saying they have probably or definitely made up their mind.  To @fisherdbus 's point - 53% of the voters also consider Biden the "Safe" choice.    Despite running neck and neck right now, Biden's national support numbers and perception as a safe candidate and his potential to beat President Trump in the general election will likely carry the day.  
All poll data pulled from https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/national/

Website '538''s more recent NH polls are varied but may indicate an edge for Sanders and Buttigieg (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primaries/democratic/new-hampshire/), but Biden appears to be distinctly leading the field nationally (https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/476681-poll-biden-holds-double-digit-lead-over-2020-democratic-rivals). Foreign policy-experienced Biden may get a boost (in weeks ahead) from Trump's conflict with Iran. Iowa winner (+ maybe runner-up) may also get a small(?) boost in NH.

Current polling gives Elizabeth Warren about 12% of the vote and the other big three 18% each. However, in previous such votes, voters switched their vote from their preferred candidate to their least-disliked/next best candidate, when their preferred candidate wasn't likely to win. Hence I expect Elizabeth Warren's vote share to fall and the other three to rise, as her supporters decide she won't win and thus vote for someone else. This is further backed up by her funding falling recently, indicating that her campaign is stalling. The question is then who her supporters will vote for, and Bernie Sanders is the most similar to her politically, especially on big topics such as the environment, education etc (ie the kind of issues which single issue voters will base their vote on). The big question therefore is whether Buttigieg or Biden can pull away, turning this vote into a two horse race, in which case I would expect that horse to beat Sanders. So far, as at star of Jan, this doesn't appear to be happening.  The other candidates' supporters - eg for Tulsi Gabbard, Andrew Yang etc - I expect to split amongst the main candidates, but generally more towards Sanders, as New Hampshire seems relatively liberal and Warren is falling away.
If Bernie can not win New Hampshire he should drop out.

After close call between Pete and Bernie in Iowa, neighbors of Vermont will get fired up and help win Bernie to a higher certainty than he experience in Iowa. Unless, if Biden wins Iowa, then Bernie can win New Hampshire with lower margin.

Polls are suggesting a strong performance from Sanders (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nh/new_hampshire_democratic_presidential_primary-6276.html). More liberal candidates tend to do better in NH.

Like the noises it has made regarding Iowa, Biden's campaign has assured itself that it doesn't need to win in New Hampshire to remain viable. Which means they expect to lose in New Hampshire.  Buttigeig has been making a respectable showing in some of the polls in New Hampshire, and his best shot is that undecided moderates will break for him, especially if he does better in Iowa than Biden. On the other hand, if Warren underperforms in Iowa, some of her support may go to Sanders, so it may wind up a wash. Sanders has the organization from last time, home-court advantage, and dedicated followers. He clobbered Hillary last time, and he will almost certainly win this time.  Warren has something of the home-court advantage, also being from a neighboring state, but as of now, she's lost any momentum. The fiscal analysis of her health plan pretty much torpedoed her candidacy.
